page.title: 16INDUSTRY_ST.MARTINS AREA
page.content: The buildings at{New Hall}used to be a farm, and a date on a stone plinth in one of the oldest barns reads{1739. There are four big dryers at{New Hall and the temperature inside them reaches between 100 degrees F. and 120 degrees F. Most of the{wood}takes{six weeks to dry. In{St. Martins}by the{Pit Mount,}where the coal mine used to be,are two{light {engineering}firms,{Browns}and{Dyke. {Browns}make aluminium{bobbins}which are used by Perkins in Shrewsbury to make diesel engines.Mr.Brown{employs 3 {local people}and{7}from outside the area.The firm has been running for a decade.{Dyke employ 9 people}who live in{St.Martins}and Oswestry.Most of them have been working there for 15 years.Their trade is to make {hydraulic parts}for tractors and J.C.B.s.They also make{rams.
